issue.title: v4.9.0 applies CVE-2021-45967 to hundreds of components
issue.body:
### Current Behavior

cpe matching got "fixed" and now CVEs with only vendors and no products erroneously match to everything ~~when fuzzy matching is enabled.  Fuzzy matching puts a wildcard in the~~ We receive sboms with * in vendor to deal with projects like apache http server and curl that have had CVEs filed under multiple vendors.    

### Steps to Reproduce

1. enable fuzzy matching
2. upload an sbom

### Expected Behavior

cpe's with an asterisk in the product position should not be fuzzy matched.

### Dependency-Track Frontend Version

4.8.x

### Browser

Google Chrome

### Browser Version

_No response_

### Operating System

Linux

### Checklist

- [X] I have read and understand the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#filing-issues)
- [X] I have checked the [existing issues](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/frontend/issues) for whether this defect was already reported

comment.body:
> FWIW CycloneDX intentionally only allows for a single CPE, as having more than one makes the component's identity ambiguous.

Hm... I would argue that having a single CPE with an additional wildcard is more ambiguous:

```
{
  cpe: "cpe:2.3:a:*:curl:7.28.0:*:*:*:*:*:*:*"
}
```

than having multiple "explizit" CPEs that are "OR'd"

```
{
  "cpe": "cpe:2.3:a:curl_project:curl:7.28.0:*:*:*:*:*:*:*",
  "cpe_aliases": [
    "cpe:2.3:a:haxx:curl:7.28.0:*:*:*:*:*:*:*"
  ]
}
```

Personally, I think this would be the "cleaner" solution as it will still be closer to the NIST CPE matching specification "as it was intended".

> The matching spec only considers one CPE attribute at a time, but doesn't cover cases where multiple attributes together don't really make sense. We could add some "common sense" filter (perhaps optional):

    If the target CPE has vendor = *, then don't match any source CPEs with product = *
    If the target CPE has product = *, then don't match any source CPEs with vendor = *
    If the target CPE has vendor = * and product = *, then ???

That being said, I do not oppose this either. The NIST specification explicitly states that adding meaning to value combinations and therefore deciding what a "match" is, is a legitimate thing to do:

![image](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/assets/12223583/98924046-c5ab-4a64-b892-19a1633947f3)

I am only concerned that we might end up going down the wrong path again once we start "redefining" what a match is, overlooking legitimate positive matches in the process.

issue.title: v4.9.0 applies CVE-2021-45967 to hundreds of components
issue.body:
### Current Behavior

cpe matching got "fixed" and now CVEs with only vendors and no products erroneously match to everything ~~when fuzzy matching is enabled.  Fuzzy matching puts a wildcard in the~~ We receive sboms with * in vendor to deal with projects like apache http server and curl that have had CVEs filed under multiple vendors.    

### Steps to Reproduce

1. enable fuzzy matching
2. upload an sbom

### Expected Behavior

cpe's with an asterisk in the product position should not be fuzzy matched.

### Dependency-Track Frontend Version

4.8.x

### Browser

Google Chrome

### Browser Version

_No response_

### Operating System

Linux

### Checklist

- [X] I have read and understand the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#filing-issues)
- [X] I have checked the [existing issues](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/frontend/issues) for whether this defect was already reported

comment.body:
> @Jasper-Ben For this kind of use-case would it be useful to have CPE "aliases" fields in CycloneDX? So instead of throwing in a wildcard for covering the handful of vendors, you could list them explicitly? And then have all the aliases checked against the CVE CPE.

FWIW CycloneDX intentionally only allows for a single CPE, as having more than one makes the component's identity ambiguous. I'd also think that, if you can't pinpoint the vendor, you'd likely need to use `ANY` anyway, as the NVD is notorious for inconsistent vendor naming. Choosing a hand full is a big gamble.

I think @officerNordberg has a point, and I'm wondering if there are legitimate cases where we'd want a match in these scenarios:

| Source Vendor | Source Product | Target Vendor | Target Product | Note |
| :------------------- | :-------------------- | :------------------ | :------------------ | :------ |
| ANY | ANY | ANY | ANY | Might as well match the entire NVD |
| ANY | foo | foo | ANY | Intention on Source side seems to be "unpredictably many vendors, just match all as long as product is the same", whereas Target side is "anything from vendor foo". The latter being a data quality problem in the NVD IMO. |
| foo | ANY | ANY | foo | Same as above, but attributes flipped |

The matching spec only considers one CPE attribute at a time, but doesn't cover cases where multiple attributes together don't really make sense. We could add some "common sense" filter (perhaps optional):

* If the target CPE has `vendor = *`, then don't match any source CPEs with `product = *`
* If the target CPE has `product = *`, then don't match any source CPEs with `vendor = *`
* If the target CPE has `vendor = *` and `product = *`, then ???

pull_request.title: Dependency track 2474
pull_request.body:
### Description

The severity value of a vulnerability is now calculated before creating the vulnerability. With this change, it is impossible that the severity field of a vulnverabilty is null in the database when a vulnerability is created.

This PR added a upgrade script (v4100) which recomputes all database severity values with value NULL of a vulnerability and updates them in the database. This is necessary because there are existing vulnerabilities in the database which have a severity value of NULL. These vulnerabilities are not effected by the changes above and their severity values have to be recalculated separately.


### Addressed Issue

#2474 


### Checklist

<!-- REQUIRED
    Mark items in this list as done by adding a `x` between the square brackets.
    Non-applicable items may be marked as such by surrounding their text with tildes (`~`).

    This is not meant to be a strict to-do list. If you're unsure about anything,
    just leave it empty for now. The maintainers are happy to assist you in figuring it out!
-->

- [x] I have read and understand the [contributing guidelines](../CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-requests)
~- [ ] This PR fixes a defect, and I have provided tests to verify that the fix is effective~
~- [ ] This PR implements an enhancement, and I have provided tests to verify that it works as intended~
- [x] This PR introduces changes to the database model, and I have added corresponding [update logic](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/tree/master/src/main/java/org/dependencytrack/upgrade)
~- [ ] This PR introduces new or alters existing behavior, and I have updated the [documentation](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/tree/master/docs/_docs) accordingly~

issue.title: v4.9.0 applies CVE-2021-45967 to hundreds of components
issue.body:
### Current Behavior

cpe matching got "fixed" and now CVEs with only vendors and no products erroneously match to everything ~~when fuzzy matching is enabled.  Fuzzy matching puts a wildcard in the~~ We receive sboms with * in vendor to deal with projects like apache http server and curl that have had CVEs filed under multiple vendors.    

### Steps to Reproduce

1. enable fuzzy matching
2. upload an sbom

### Expected Behavior

cpe's with an asterisk in the product position should not be fuzzy matched.

### Dependency-Track Frontend Version

4.8.x

### Browser

Google Chrome

### Browser Version

_No response_

### Operating System

Linux

### Checklist

- [X] I have read and understand the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#filing-issues)
- [X] I have checked the [existing issues](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/frontend/issues) for whether this defect was already reported

comment.body:
> We receive sboms with * in vendor to deal with projects like apache http server and curl that have had CVEs filed under multiple vendors.

The way CPE matching worked before v4.9.0, setting `*` as vendor would result in false negatives: https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/issues/2580, unless the Fuzzy matching would by chance happen to "fuzz" all the correct CPEs, that is if fuzzy matching was enabled.

Basically, from a matching rule perspective this is a binary decision. We are stuck between hiding potential security risks by not treating `*` in CVE CPE as a match for a string `n` in component CPE (as was done < v.4.9.0) or having false positives when component CPE data is given that is incomplete. I for one prefer the latter and instead look for ways to better deal with the odd false positive.

> We receive sboms with * in vendor to deal with projects like apache http server and curl that have had CVEs filed under multiple vendors.

For this kind of use-case would it be useful to have CPE "aliases" fields in CycloneDX? So instead of throwing in a wildcard for covering the handful of vendors, you could list them explicitly? And then have all the aliases checked against the CVE CPE. @nscuro what do you think?

issue.title: v4.9.0 applies CVE-2021-45967 to hundreds of components
issue.body:
### Current Behavior

cpe matching got "fixed" and now CVEs with only vendors and no products erroneously match to everything ~~when fuzzy matching is enabled.  Fuzzy matching puts a wildcard in the~~ We receive sboms with * in vendor to deal with projects like apache http server and curl that have had CVEs filed under multiple vendors.    

### Steps to Reproduce

1. enable fuzzy matching
2. upload an sbom

### Expected Behavior

cpe's with an asterisk in the product position should not be fuzzy matched.

### Dependency-Track Frontend Version

4.8.x

### Browser

Google Chrome

### Browser Version

_No response_

### Operating System

Linux

### Checklist

- [X] I have read and understand the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#filing-issues)
- [X] I have checked the [existing issues](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/frontend/issues) for whether this defect was already reported

comment.body:
:wave:

The current behavior "works as intended" (at least according to the CPE matching specification). When having a `*` in your components vendor CPE, everything else will match with the CVE CPE `cpe:2.3:a:pascom_cloud_phone_system:*:*:*:*:*:*:*:*:*` (which has `*` for basically every other attribute, so it matches with anything else your component CPE throws out there).

I am not sure how to fix this, without bringing back false negatives. Maybe an easy way of "clearing" a CVE from an entire project, not only on component basis would lessen the pain of dealing with this kind of situation?

issue.title: v4.9.0 applies CVE-2021-45967 to hundreds of components
issue.body:
### Current Behavior

cpe matching got "fixed" and now CVEs with only vendors and no products erroneously match to everything ~~when fuzzy matching is enabled.  Fuzzy matching puts a wildcard in the~~ We receive sboms with * in vendor to deal with projects like apache http server and curl that have had CVEs filed under multiple vendors.    

### Steps to Reproduce

1. enable fuzzy matching
2. upload an sbom

### Expected Behavior

cpe's with an asterisk in the product position should not be fuzzy matched.

### Dependency-Track Frontend Version

4.8.x

### Browser

Google Chrome

### Browser Version

_No response_

### Operating System

Linux

### Checklist

- [X] I have read and understand the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#filing-issues)
- [X] I have checked the [existing issues](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/frontend/issues) for whether this defect was already reported

comment.body:
Here's the issue. I don't know what this should be, but it certainly results in a weird "full outer join" of a match between ANY vendor and ANY product.  I can't think of any good solution to this other than a janky config or not adding * to the query as you move left to right in the parsedCpe if you've already encountered a '*'.  

` SELECT FROM org.dependencytrack.model.VulnerableSoftware WHERE ((part == '*' || part == :part) && vendor != null && (product == '*' || product == :product))`


https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/blob/master/src/main/java/org/dependencytrack/persistence/VulnerableSoftwareQueryManager.java#L266

issue.title: Please document how the "Risk Score" is calculated
issue.body:
We're adopting Dependency Track as part of a cybersecurity improvement project. We don't yet have a formal risk analysis and management framework. In this "transitional" period, we want to use whatever is built into Dependency Track. We see the "Risk Score" column in the "Components" tab, but we don't know how this is calculated.

We see that the "Exploit Predictions" tab provides CVSS and EPSS scores, but these are by vulnerability, not component. Are these rolled up into the overall component "Risk Score"?

Anyway, we'd love to see some documentation on this so that we can move forward with a transitional plan.

Thank you!

comment.body: Wouldn't it be better for that score to be normalized - I.e. divide the above by the sum of critical + high + medium + low + unassigned?  That way the score will always be between 0 and 10 (assume 0 if the denominator is 0).

issue.title: Helm Repo / Helm Chart
issue.body:
### Current Behavior

There is no public helm repository / helm chart from the project.

### Proposed Behavior

It would be great if there would be a public helm repository for DepenencyTrack, There is no easy clean way to deploy the software on a cloud native stack like k8s. There is a helm third party chart, but it is noch maintained / updated. For us this is a showstopper to use this great software in live deployment because, maintainance is manual this way and not possible via renovate bot etc.

Greetings,
Martin

### Checklist

- [X] I have read and understand the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#filing-issues)
- [X] I have checked the [existing issues](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/issues) for whether this enhancement was already requested

comment.body: A year ago we were looking for the same ting, but can’t sit around and wait, but maintaining this: https://github.com/nais/dependencytrack

commits.message:
WIP: Improve performance of search index operations

Signed-off-by: nscuro <nscuro@protonmail.com>

Fetch index-able records in batches of <= 2500

Instead of fetching them all in one go. Additionally, don't fetch entire records, but only those fields that are needed to populate the index.

Signed-off-by: nscuro <nscuro@protonmail.com>

Update indexer tests to use new `SearchDocument` objects

Signed-off-by: nscuro <nscuro@protonmail.com>

Object passed to `IndexEvent` no longer need detaching

They are converted to non-managed `SearchDocument` implementations in `IndexEvent`'s constructor.

Signed-off-by: nscuro <nscuro@protonmail.com>

Optimize batch sizes for reindex; Commit index more frequently

Signed-off-by: nscuro <nscuro@protonmail.com>

Prevent `IndexEvent` from being singleton

As `IndexEvent`s are being handled in the single-threaded event service, they'll be handled serially. Dispatching them multiple times is mostly unproblematic.

The logic in `SearchManager#reindex` is not working as expected when the event is a singleton, because chain identifiers are inherited from the first event in the chain, causing #2987.

Fixes #2987

Signed-off-by: nscuro <nscuro@protonmail.com>

Fix race conditions in `SearchResourceTest`

Signed-off-by: nscuro <nscuro@protonmail.com>

Fix `instanceof` checking for incorrect classes

`getDocument` returns objects of `*Document` types now.

Signed-off-by: nscuro <nscuro@protonmail.com>

Fix test failures due to already closed `PersistenceManager`

Signed-off-by: nscuro <nscuro@protonmail.com>

Merge pull request #3116 from nscuro/improve-index-performance

Improve efficiency of index operations

pull_request.title: Improve efficiency of index operations
pull_request.body:
### Description

This PR improves index operations in the following ways:

For all indexing operations (`CREATE`, `UPDATE`, `DELETE`):

* Dispatch `IndexEvent`s with designated `SearchDocument` record classes, instead of persistent objects
  * Removes the need to `detach` persistent objects, which sometimes involved additional database operations behind the scenes
  * Lowers memory footprint slightly because queued events are smaller

For reindexing:

* Fetch database records in batches of 500-1000, instead of fetching *all* at once
  * Fetching all at once does not scale and doesn't work anymore once the portfolio surpasses a few thousand projects
* Use keyset pagination to speed up fetch requests
* Use projections to fetch records, with only the required fields, instead of the full-blown model classes
  * Avoids ORM overhead, reduces memory footprint and network traffic

Additionally, this PR addresses #2987 by removing the singleton property from `IndexEvent`.

These changes were originally implented in [hyades](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/hyades-apiserver).

### Addressed Issue

<!-- REQUIRED
    Reference the issue addressed by this PR, e.g. `#1234`.
    Use keywords like `closes` or `fixes` to signal that this PR resolves the issue,
    causing the issue to be closed automatically when the PR is merged:
        https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue#linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue-using-a-keyword
-->

Fixes #2987

### Additional Details

<!-- OPTIONAL
    If desired, share more technical details about the change here.
    Elaborating on why you implemented the change the way you did can be super helpful to the reviewer.
    Did you consider other solutions? Any problems you ran into along the way?
-->

N/A

### Checklist

<!-- REQUIRED
    Mark items in this list as done by adding a `x` between the square brackets.
    Non-applicable items may be marked as such by surrounding their text with tildes (`~`).

    This is not meant to be a strict to-do list. If you're unsure about anything,
    just leave it empty for now. The maintainers are happy to assist you in figuring it out!
-->

- [x] I have read and understand the [contributing guidelines](../CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-requests)
- [x] This PR fixes a defect, and I have provided tests to verify that the fix is effective
- [x] This PR implements an enhancement, and I have provided tests to verify that it works as intended
- ~This PR introduces changes to the database model, and I have added corresponding [update logic](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/tree/master/src/main/java/org/dependencytrack/upgrade)~
- ~This PR introduces new or alters existing behavior, and I have updated the [documentation](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/tree/master/docs/_docs) accordingly~

issue.title: why only busybox has cve?
issue.body:
### Current Behavior

upload a sbom file
but only busybox has cve
![image](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/assets/26828709/90d80888-16f2-4b94-8f0a-c64d0d300331)


### Steps to Reproduce

1.

### Expected Behavior

output cve 

### Dependency-Track Version

4.7.x

### Dependency-Track Distribution

Container Image

### Database Server

PostgreSQL

### Database Server Version

_No response_

### Browser

Google Chrome

### Checklist

- [X] I have read and understand the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#filing-issues)
- [X] I have checked the [existing issues](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/issues) for whether this defect was already reported

comment.body:
@chenjianquan7 Other than the `busybox` one, none of the CPEs in that SBOM have any matches in the NVD. It seems like whatever tool you used to generate the SBOM populated the `vendor` attribute of the CPE with the `product` attribute's value.

If you change `cpe:2.3:a:libcurl:libcurl:7.65.1:*:*:*:*:*:*:*` to `cpe:2.3:a:*:libcurl:7.65.1:*:*:*:*:*:*:*` (changing the `vendor` from `libcurl` to `*`), you'll get vulnerabilities. The same can be done for the other components in your SBOM.

Also note that the Linux kernel is tracked as operating system by the NVD (the `part` attribute is `o` not `a`), and the `product` attribute is `linux_kernel`, not `kernel`: https://nvd.nist.gov/products/cpe/search/results?namingFormat=2.3&keyword=cpe%3A2.3%3Ao%3Alinux%3Alinux_kernel%3A3.10.14%3A*%3A*%3A*%3A*%3A*%3A*%3A*

The NVD has a CPE search functionality where you can validate whether your CPEs are valid: https://nvd.nist.gov/products/cpe/

issue.title: v4.9.0 applies CVE-2021-45967 to hundreds of components when fuzzy matching is enabled.
issue.body:
### Current Behavior

cpe matching got "fixed" and now CVEs with only vendors and no products erroneously match to everything when fuzzy matching is enabled.  Fuzzy matching puts a wildcard in the vendor space to deal with projects like apache http server and curl that have had CVEs filed under multiple vendors.    

### Steps to Reproduce

1. enable fuzzy matching
2. upload an sbom

### Expected Behavior

cpe's with an asterisk in the product position should not be fuzzy matched.

### Dependency-Track Frontend Version

4.8.x

### Browser

Google Chrome

### Browser Version

_No response_

### Operating System

Linux

### Checklist

- [X] I have read and understand the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#filing-issues)
- [X] I have checked the [existing issues](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/frontend/issues) for whether this defect was already reported

comment.body:
You're saying we need an additional `&& !"*".equals(search.getProduct())` here?

https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/blob/fe394cc254be02bfffc50f597e4f75bbe3611bcb/src/main/java/org/dependencytrack/search/FuzzyVulnerableSoftwareSearchManager.java#L128-L130

issue.title: CBOM: Add CycloneDX v1.6 support for cryptographic assets

labels.name: p2
labels.description: Non-critical bugs, and features that help organizations to identify and reduce risk

issue.body:
### Current Behavior

Currently, Dependency-Track does not support cryptographic assets.

### Proposed Behavior

Add support for cryptographic assets and their dependencies once CycloneDX v1.6 is released.

- Display cryptographic assets in inventory
- Display cryptographic assets in dependency graph
- Display cryptographic-specific fields in component view and modal dialogs
- Add support for dependency types (display on dependency graph)

NOTE: May be able to reach out to IBM Quantum for a git patch or PR, as they've performed an internal fork of DT that adds support for some of these things already.

### Checklist

- [X] I have read and understand the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#filing-issues)
- [X] I have checked the [existing issues](https://github.com/DependencyTrack/dependency-track/issues) for whether this enhancement was already requested

issue.title: Add support for multiple licenses

labels.name: p2
labels.description: Non-critical bugs, and features that help organizations to identify and reduce risk

issue.body:
Components are often released under multiple licenses. SPDX license expressions provide this, and other capabilities.

https://github.com/CycloneDX/specification/issues/1

comment.body: After uploading a BOM file with the correct "expression" key/value pair in the license list, I was able to verify that dependency track correctly handles the SPDX expression. I'll raise the issue to the maintainer of my SBOM generation tool. Thank you @nscuro for your insights.

comment.body: After reviewing the CycloneDX 1.4 spec, it seems this tool does not generate the correct SBOM output given a SPDX expression, as defined [here](https://cyclonedx.org/docs/1.4/json/#components_items_licenses_items_expression).
